summary: This is an email from Chris DiIon forwarding an appeal regarding a denial of action related to Knight Capital TCR, with attached documents. The email contains allegations of corruption at the SEC, references to various companies and audit firms, and mentions a PCAOB disciplinary order. This document is a series of emails from whistleblower Chris Dilorio to various SEC officials, judges, and others, alleging massive, ongoing securities fraud facilitated by the SEC. Dilorio claims the SEC is corrupt, obstructs investigations, protects criminal entities like Knight Capital (NITE), and denies whistleblower awards while enabling money laundering through OTC market shells.

persons.name: Chris DiIon
persons.context: Appears as the sender of the email forwarding an appeal regarding a denial of action and making allegations about SEC corruption.

persons.name: Brian D. Donahue
persons.context: Named as a respondent in a PCAOB disciplinary order referenced in the email for sanctions imposed on June 14, 2016.

persons.name: Chris Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the emails, alleging SEC corruption, obstruction, and facilitation of massive securities fraud and money laundering.

persons.name: Gary Gensler
persons.context: Addressed in emails, urged to discuss allegations of SEC corruption and fraud facilitation.

persons.name: Barry Honig
persons.context: Named as a key figure in fraudulent schemes involving money laundering shells, linked to Jaclin, Frost, and others.

persons.name: Michael Farkas

persons.name: Jay Clayton
persons.context: Accused of undisclosed conflicts, obstruction, and facilitating fraud through his former firm Sullivan & Cromwell.

persons.name: Steve Schwarzman

persons.name: Jared Kushner

persons.name: David Lazar

persons.context: Involved in Hanover/Magna frauds, NewLead, FreeSeas, and other money laundering shells.

persons.name: Justin Keener

persons.name: Moses Marx

persons.name: Oleg Firer
persons.context: Prolific bag man linked to Acies Corp, Rovt, Allied Wallet, and WireCard.

persons.name: Terren Peizer
persons.context: Milken associate involved in Net Element, Crede, and Deutsche Bank frauds.

persons.name: Bill Richardson

connections.description: Dilorio addresses Gensler directly, urging him to discuss SEC corruption and fraud facilitation.
Both involved in money laundering shells like Blink Charging and linked to Jaclin's shell factory.
Former colleagues at Sullivan & Cromwell; Fishman accused of helping keep NITE running.
Former colleagues at Paul Weiss; Mehraban accused of obstructing investigations to protect Cifu's NITE.
Described as BFFs; both involved in Kodak pump-and-dump and SEC 'do not investigate' list.
Both bag men involved in money laundering shells and fraudulent schemes detailed in Dilorio's TCRs.
Longtime business partners involved in Berkshire Bancorp and Kodak insider trading.
Partners in Zenith Partners, controlling numerous money laundering shells.
Mentioned as connected; part of broader network of wealthy associates.
Norberg denied Dilorio's Oppenheimer whistleblower claim after 5 years.

events.title: PCAOB Disciplinary Order Against Donahue Associates
events.description: The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB) issued an order instituting disciplinary proceedings, making findings, and imposing sanctions against Donahue Associates LLC and Brian D. Donahue, CPA.

events.title: Knight Capital Trading Glitch
events.description: Knight Capital (NITE) suffered a catastrophic trading glitch that dropped its stock from $10.30 to $2.50, leading to a bailout by Blackstone, Goldman Sachs, Jefferies, and others.

events.title: SEC Charges Barry Honig et al.
events.description: SEC charged Barry Honig and others for fraudulent schemes generating over $27 million from unlawful stock sales.

events.title: SEC Approves Blink Charging Offering
events.description: SEC approved a public offering for Blink Charging (BLNK) despite whistleblower allegations it was a money laundering shell.

events.title: Blink Charging Fraudulent PR
events.description: Blink Charging issued a press release about charging station grants, driving stock up 27% without filing an 8-K, alleged to be a pump-and-dump.

events.title: Kodak DFC Loan Announcement
events.description: Eastman Kodak announced a $765 million loan from the U.S. International Development Finance Corporation (DFC) to produce pharmaceuticals, leading to a massive stock pump-and-dump.

events.title: Hometown International Fraud Exposure
events.description: Dilorio highlights Hometown International (HWIN), a New Jersey deli with a $100M market cap and investors in Macau/Hong Kong, as an example of ongoing OTC market fraud.

events.title: SEC Whistleblower Rule Change
events.description: SEC adopted new Rule 240.21F-18 allowing summary denial of whistleblower awards if staff never saw the information, dubbed the 'Christopher J Dilorio Rule'.

keyFacts: The email forwards a formal appeal for a denial of action related to 'Knight Capital TCR & Appendix' dated April 21, 2021.
It alleges the SEC is 'grossly corrupt' and references a 2004 10-K filing for C2E Energy/Advanced Sports/Odyssey Energy, audited by 'Webb and Company'.
It lists numerous companies (e.g., Finotec, MediaShift, Rarus, Petrone Worldwide) as 'money laundering shells' that are SEC-reporting and allegedly still operating.
It references a 2016 PCAOB disciplinary order against Donahue Associates LLC and Brian D. Donahue, CPA.
The sender implies a connection between these financial entities/auditors and broader corruption, possibly hinting at a network, but no direct link to Jeffrey Epstein is made in this text chunk.

Chris Dilorio alleges the SEC is a 'grossly corrupt, criminal entity' that actively facilitates massive securities fraud and money laundering while obstructing investigations and denying whistleblower awards.
Knight Capital (NITE/VIRT) is accused of being a criminal enterprise whose core business is abusive naked shorting of OTC market shells to facilitate money laundering, with SEC complicity.
Numerous individuals like Barry Honig, Michael Farkas, Josh Sason, and David Lazar are named as 'bag men' operating networks of money laundering shells, many still active in 2021.
The SEC is accused of creating the 'Christopher J Dilorio Rule' (Rule 240.21F-18) to deny whistleblower awards by claiming staff never saw the information, despite years of correspondence.
High-profile figures like Steve Schwarzman, Donald Trump, Jared Kushner, and Jeffrey Epstein are linked to alleged frauds such as the Kodak DFC loan pump-and-dump and Blink Charging schemes.
